reviewText:
I am a big fan of Aces of the Galaxy, a game that this borrows heavily from. I really wanted to enjoy this game for what it's worth, but the aiming system in the game completely ruins it. I think the graphics, presentation, audio and controls are all spot on. I wish more indie devs would tackle mindless fun like this, but the aiming takes away any enjoyment.

I understand that the devs wanted the shooting to be simplistic and just focus on the center of the screen with a sort of auto-aim function, but this really takes away from the game. It's an on-rails shooter where you don't aim and really only control your dogding. The dodging part is great, but why couldn't they just follow the design aspects of Aces of the Galaxy and let you aim your guns and modify the missile lock on system to be a bit more responsive. If there was a crossair you controlled to aim your guns, and the missile lock on system required you to hold it down to lock on then release to fire, this would be a much much better game that I could recommend.

Pros:

Adequate Visuals, Audio and Presentation.
Good movement controls.
Attempt at a genre lacking modern titles. Aims to be simple and fun.

Cons:

Aiming system is a complete failure and takes all the fun out of combat.
Weapons could provide more of a visual response.
Better indication of the amount of damage you're doing as well as receiving.

reviewText:
A solid Star Fox style casual game, worth the price.

The audiovisuals are really well done and create a good sense of action. Balancing is worth a mention - Normal difficulty has some challenges, but not too frustrating, while Hard makes you constantly fight for your life. It's rare to see that nowadays.

The main problem is the aiming - Star Horizon forgoes having a reticle in favor of visually lining up your ship with your target. It generally works well and doesn't get in the way. But:
it's underexplained, which means you have to figure out this quite counterintuitive idea by yourself
it breaks the immersion - it depends on how you look at the scene from the third person perspective, reminding you that you don't actually pilot the ship
you obscure the target with your ship, so if it shoots back at you, you won't see that
There are also some decisions to be made during flight, which makes for a nice touch of variety, and a simple customization system which goes well with the complexity level of the game.

Once you grasp the aiming, you will be having some solid fun.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nhZTkG7hQZk
Star Horizon is a new rails shooter releasing on Steam that's actually a port of a mobile iOS game.  But is the port any good and does it stand on it's own playing the PC version on Steam?  I've had a chance to test it for a few hours, so let's find out in this first impression of Star Horizon.

Many would immediately compare Star Horizon to the old school Starfox Nintendo games mainly because there's not a lot of rail shooters these days.  Star Horizon is not a Starfox clone, it's a sci fi shooter.  There is a struggle between the Inter Galactic Corporation known as the Federation and the Rebel Alliance.  You play as John a private pilot of the federation and your companion is Ellie the AI on your ship.  Your role is to find out what's really happening in this war.

There's simple cutscenes that take place over voice communication and there is plenty of banter between John and Ellie.  The voice acting fits and helps the game flow a little better, but the story is not incredibly deep.

Although the game was originally designed for touch screens, the PC version supports Xbox controllers.  Your ship is outfitted with your primary weapon the laser.  But you have to be lined up directly behind enemies in order to hit which is different from typical rails shooters and a little difficult to aim, but you get used to it.  Then you have homing missiles and torpedos which have unlimited ammo, but are on a cooldown.  Both your weapons and armor can be upgraded in the hanger in between missions.  There's also a dodge mechanic which comes in handy.

Combat is fast and keeps you busy but there are moments when the difficulty increases significantly for certain sections.  Even on easy certain sections seem difficult to pass without upgrades due to the amount of enemies.  I wish the difficulty scaled a little better in these sections.

As far as the port from Mobile to PC, there's a lot of benefits but a few disadvantages.  The graphics are nice and it even supports anti aliasing and ultra settings.  Your ship and your the effects of your attacks look very detailed and the space atmosphere is immersive.   I still feel like the primary weapon shooting needs to have a reticle with a bit of lead time like in Starfox.  Then in the hanger upgrades section the scaling seems off.  Running 1080p, the menu options are fair sized, but the text on the ship upgrades is so small it's illegible.

There's not a lot of space rail shooters on Steam and this game is pretty fun for a short ride.  Check it out on Steam if you want a fun space shooter. Subscribe to the skilled channel for more game reviews.

Fast Rail Shooter

Negatives:

Mobile Interface issues

reviewText:
Star Horizon is an extremely refreshing game in an endless sea of platformers and brawlers. Harkening from the space-battle gameplay of games like Star Fox, Star Horizon puts you in the pilot seat of an interstellar aircraft.

Like Star Fox, it's a bit of a rail-shooter. The ship's AI sets a course to your objective, and it's up to you to dodge and navigate your way through space debris, laser fire, and other ships in an epic space battle. This is something the game does very well, with the play setting, as the space battle erupting around you feels epic and massive, leaving you to feel like a small cog in a larger machine. Massive ships float around you, while smaller fighter ships spiral around shooting laser fire at your fragile shields.

I haven't played that much yet, but I've learned that there is a huge underlying narrative driven by player-choice (similar to a Telltale style game). This very ambitious title plays extremely well, with excellent controls and a truly epic feel. The ONLY issues I've noticed thus far are audio issues (whoever equalized the game... didn't.) and the fact that I feel like my primary attack is completely useless. The rockets work just fine, but when shooting the laser guns, I never feel like I know where I'm shooting. Apart from that, this is a very cool indie game, and one I intend on spending a lot more time with.
